moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 g6: Signalling Black's intention to play the Accelerated Dragon
moves.3. Bc4 Bg7 4. c3 Nc6 5. d4 cxd4 6. cxd4: Not only supports the d5 square but also closes down the diagonal for White's light squared Bishop
moves.11. Nbd2 Nf5: I took the decision to win the Bishop pair
moves.12. Re1 Nxe3 13. Rxe3 Qb6: Putting pressure on White's centre.  The d-pawn cannot advance with hanging the e-pawn
Clearly not 18. Bxd5?? losing to Rxc8
moves.20... Qb7: Allowing the Rook to come to c8 and perhaps some potential for play along the a8-h1 diagonal
moves.21. Ne2 Rc8 22. Nf4 Rxc3 23. bxc3 Bxf3 2: Exchanging into an endgame with the better minor piece; with play on both sides of the board the Bishop should be able to outplay the Knight
moves.25... Bf8: Pushing the a-pawn and thereby allowing Black to capture it is an unstoppable passed pawn that will eventually Queen
The position is now easily won for Black
moves.30... Bxd4 31. f4 Bc3 32. Kg2 b4 33. Nc5: A better plan for White may have been to create counter-play on the kingside
moves.37. Kc4 Bd2 38. Nd3 Kc6 39. Nxb4+: The last mistake after which White could have resigned
